metadata.title: Endovascular treatment of a ruptured pararenal abdominal aortic aneurysm in a COVID-19 patient: suggestions and case report Endovascular treatment of a ruptured pararenal abdominal aortic aneurysm in a COVID-19 1 patient: suggestions and case report 2 3 Endovascular treatment of a ruptured pararenal abdominal aortic aneurysm in a COVID-19

abstract.text: The aim of this report is to discuss emergent repair for complex aortic diseases in patients affected 30

body_text.text: aneurysm (AAA) is to offer some consideration on this matter from the standpoint of a hub Hospital 50 for COVID-19 patients in Lombardy, the Italian region that has been affected the most by the 51 pandemics. showing a free rupture of the pararenal abdominal aorta, right above the previous endograft at the 67 level of the renal arteries, and a massive intraperitoneal hematoma (figg.2,3). Open surgical 68 treatment was excluded, not only due to the technical difficulty caused by a hostile abdomen and 69 the need to explant the endograft, but also because a laparotomy would have necessarily worsened 70 the respiratory impairment and probably yielded to a severe respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). On post-operative day II, he performed a CTA showed a type IA endoleak due to slight caudad 95 migration of the aortic cuff, with reduction of the retroperitoneal hematoma (figg.6,7). 96
Reintervention was carried out, with surgical access at the right CFA and the left brachial artery. 97

From the brachial access, a Gore introducer 9x70 was placed at the origin of the SMA, which was 98 engaged from above, and a covered stent (VBX 7x59 mm) ® (Gore &Ass, Flagstaff, Arizona, US) 99 was inserted. From the CFA access, a Gore ® endograft aortic cuff 32x45 was placed right below the Theoretically, non-COVID urgencies should be referred to other centers, but often these patients 155 cannot be safely transferred, so it is of the utmost importance to have a protocol for all those cases 156 requiring non-deferrable treatment. The one followed in our Center consists in early screening for 157 COVID-19 through nasal swab and chest X-ray for all patients accessing to the Emergency Room 158 (ER), and separate routes for in-hospital admission for COVID and non-COVID patients. The 159 operatory theaters and the hospital wards are also divided between COVID-free and COVID-19 160 patients. If COVID-19 positivity cannot be determined before admission and surgery, the patients is 161 managed through the "clean" route, but with all precaution of staff individual protection and room 162 sanification that are employed for COVID-patients. In the present case, the result of the nasal swab 163 was only available after the first intervention began, but the patient was considered COVID-19 164 positive since the beginning based on the chest X-ray. All these considerations are crucial to contain 165 the viral spread among in-hospital patients and were extremely helpful in choosing the most 166 suitable approach of treatment. 167
As acknowledged above, the risk of failure of emergent parallel grafting in ruptured AAAs is high, 168 ranging between 10% and 26%, but the most common complications of EVAR, namely endoleak,

FIGREF0.text: of the patient's data was approved by the competent Institutional Review 56 Board. 57 An 80-year-old man, undergone endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) in 2013 for an infrarenal AAA 58 and lost to follow-up for 5 years, was referred to the Unit of Vascular Surgery for severe abdominal 59 pain, hypotension (blood pressure: 60/35 mmHg) and eventually loss of consciousness. Most 60 significant comorbidities were previous rectal cancer, treated by Hartman resection and left terminal 61 colostomy confection, post-incisional hernia of the abdominal midline and chronic kidney failure 62 with left kidney shrinkage. Although no respiratory symptom such as dyspnea, cough or fever was 63 reported, the routine chest X-ray performed at the admittance showed a consolidation pattern 64 spreading at the inferior lobes of the lungs (fig.1) and the nasal swab turned positive for NCoV (lab 65 tests are reported in table 1). A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) was performed, 66

FIGREF1.text: 71 Endovascular repair was therefore chosen, although the emergent setting left no time to purchase 72 the most suitable devices and the repair had to be carried out with the stocks available in the 73 hospital warehouse. 74 Under general anesthesia, a micro-surgical access was obtained at the right common femoral artery 75 (CFA), while the left was approached percutaneously. Introducers Cook ® 8x45mm and Cook ® 76 7x45mm (Cook Medical Inc, Bloomington, Indiana, US) were placed in the left and right CFA 77 respectively. The right renal artery was engaged from the left access with a 6F catheter. On the right 78 side, the introducer was switched with a Gore ® 18F introducer (Gore & Ass, Flagstaff, Arizona, 79 US) and an angiogram was performed, showing aortic rupture right above the left renal artery 80 (LRA), which was barely visible (fig.4). Due to the shrinkage of the left kidney, it was decided that 81 the left renal artery could be sacrificed and only the right renal artery (RRA) was revascularized. On 82 a guide wire V18, two Viabhan ® 7x50mm and 8x100mm (Gore & Ass, Flagstaff, Arizona, US) 83 were placed in the RRA. A Gore ® aortic cuff sized 32x45 mm was placed right below the origin of 84 the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and deployed with intentional covering of the LRA. The two 85 Viabahn ® (periscope technique) were then deployed and they were post-dilated simultaneously with 86 the cuff (Cordis Opta Pro ® 7x100, Cordis Corp., Milpitas, CA, US, was used for the stentgrafts and 87 Reliant ® , Medtronic Inc, Minneapolis, Minnesota, US, for the cuff). At the completion angiogram, 88 complete exclusion of the aneurysm was observed, with patency of the SMA and RRA (fig.5). The 89 patient was extubated at the awakening and showed quick recovery of the vital parameters (BP:

FIGREF2.text: coeliac trunk (CT) origin and deployed along with the SMA VBX ® after safety engagement of the 101 right renal Viabahn. Completion angiography showed absence of leak and patency of the CT, SMA 102 and RRA (fig.8). 103After awakening and extubation, the patient was stable and in good clinical conditions and was 104 transferred to the Internal Medicine Ward for an observation period due to the COVID-19 105 pneumonia, which showed a stepwise but constant recovery during the post-operative course 106 (improvement of the lung translucency at the chest X-ray on post-operative day XII and drop of cof complex AAAs involving the renal arteries, whether with fenestrated, 112 branched endografts or parallel grafting, has been largely validated in the latest years, and it has 113 proven safe and effective, provided that adequate surgical expertise and suitable endovascular 114 materials are available.2 Those conditions still limit the feasibility of EVAR of pararenal aneurysms 115 in emergent settings, especially in case of free rupture and hemodynamic instability, with little time 116 for accurate planning and sizing and often lack of the optimal endograft size. 3 In those situations, 117 open repair is still considered the treatment of choice, despite the heavy burden of possible 118 complications in a high-risk patient, as in this case: in fact, open repair would have required delayed 119 conversion of the previous EVAR with endograft explant, and the presence of a left colostomy, 120 midline laparocele and intraperitoneal hematoma, would have made the access to the aorta 121 extremely difficult and time-consuming, with a considerable damage of the respiratory mechanism 122 and a prolonged condition of respiratory distress. The patient was actually asymptomatic for 123 respiratory infection, but the imaging and lab tests showed clear signs of a moderate-to-severe 124 involvement of the pulmonary area and initial signs of systemic involvement. Although no specific 125 indication has been given yet about the management of COVID-19 patients warranting urgent aortic 126 surgery, the consequences of laparotomy on the respiratory system are well known, especially in 127 already compromised patients, and so is the great advantage of EVAR over open aortic surgery in 128 terms of pulmonary involvement 4 ; therefore the advanced endovascular treatment was the most 129 reasonable choice, even in absence of a wide selection of endovascular materials covering all 130 possible sizes. Parallel grafting has already been described in semi-urgent, urgent and even 131 emergent settings, with satisfactory outcomes, including lower mortality and lower complication 132 rate and shorter Intensive Care Unit (ICU) stay, and its role can result even more precious now, in 133 order to avoid open surgery in COVID-19 patients. 3 In this respect, the importance of having a wide 134 variety of endovascular devices stored in the hospital warehouse is crucial, since it offers the 135 possibility to treat safely many and different types of aortic diseases and anatomic configurations, 136 not only in urgency, but also in elective settings, since supplies could be delayed due to the 137 lockdown and other measures to contain the viral spread. 138 In the present case, a longer proximal neck could have been obtained by performing a chimney graft 139 on the SMA from the beginning, which would have spared the patients the second intervention, but 140 the emergent conditions of the patients (hemorrhagic shock with hemodynamic instability) made it 141 preferable to try for a quicker and less invasive treatment. That was in fact successful in excluding 142 the aneurysm and stop the intraperitoneal hemorrhage, as demonstrated by the hemodynamic 143 stabilization and the CTA, and made it possible to perform the reintervention on a stable patient, in 144 non-emergent setting. Although EVAR is at high risk for late failure and complications, and despite 145 being technically demanding due to the parallel grafting, endovascular repair appears in those cases 146 the treatment of choice, because it represents the safest and quickest way to stop the hemorrhage 147 preserving the respiratory function. In fact, not only did the patient regain his consciousness and 148 hemodynamic stability shortly after the end of the procedure, but he was also extubated and has had 149 no further need for ventilatory support so far. Moreover, endovascular repair avoided post-operative 150 ICU stay, which would have been necessary in case of open repair, in a moment of dramatic 151 shortage of beds due to the critically ill COVID-19 patients. The outbreak of COVID-19 in Northern Italy, in fact, has imposed the conversion of many hospitals, including ours, in COVID-19 153 dedicated centers, with only little resources available for the management of other urgencies. 154

FIGREF3.text: 169 can be addressed by endovascular treatment, which makes the risk of failure less worrisome than 170 the perspective of an open conversion. 5 171 The last suggestion regarding the management of COVID-19 patients needing urgent aortic surgery 172 regards anticoagulation: in fact, although the incidence of thrombotic events in these patients is still 173 unknown, an altered coagulation profile and an increased tendency to develop micro-and macro-174 thromboses in both arterial and venous system have been confirmed by several authors, so early 175 anticoagulation with systemic heparin administration should be started in all these patients before 176 starting endovascular procedures. 6,7 177 Conclusions 179 180 Despite being a single case report, this is to our knowledge the first experience regarding emergent 181 complex aortic surgery in a COVID-19 patient. The main suggestions that can be drawn from this 182 regard the benefits of endovascular surgery, even in absence of adequate materials, the importance 183 of keeping a well-supplied warehouse and early systemic anticoagulation prior to surgery. Minimal 184 invasivity and prevention of the complications, in fact, are the key to manage the vascular urgency 185 and avoid progression of the infection, that can evolve from pneumonia to multi-organ failure.
